Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10974555?af=R拉曼光谱杂志目录。最新期和 EarlyView 期的文章列表。 en-US © 约翰·威利父子有限公司wileyonlinelibrary@wiley.com（分析科学期刊） Mon, 23 Oct 2023 07:04:10 +0000 2023 年 10 月 23 日星期一 07:04:10 +0000 Atypon®文学™ https://validator.w3.org/feed/docs/rss2.html 10080 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录威利拉曼光谱杂志 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/pb-assets/journal-banners/10974555.jpg https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10974555?af=R https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6614?af=R Fri, 20 Oct 2023 00:44:42 -0700 2023-10-20T12:44:42-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录 10.1002/jrs.6614地质拉曼 2022拉曼光谱学杂志，EarlyView。亚当·库尔卡、扬·杰利卡特刊-社论地质拉曼 2022 10.1002/jrs.6614拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6614 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6614?af=R 特刊-社论 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6608?af=R Wed, 18 Oct 2023 05:08:52 -0700 2023-10-18T05:08:52-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录 10.1002/jrs.6608用于散装 sp2 和 sp3 碳材料自动分类的机器学习方法拉曼光谱学杂志，EarlyView。碳材料呈现出独特的拉曼特征，该特征取决于各种因素，包括主要的碳杂化。获得了多种碳材料的参考光谱，并将其用作机器学习算法的训练集。该程序可以对文献中报道的拉曼光谱库进行自动分类，准确度很高（97%）。摘要 使用主成分分析（PCA）和线性判别分析（LDA）根据拉曼光谱对不同类型的碳材料进行分类。所选参考材料为高取向热解石墨（HOPG）、类金刚石碳（DLC）、玻璃碳（GC）、氢化类石墨碳（GLCH）和氢化类聚合物碳（PLCH）。这些材料的结晶度、主要碳杂化和氢含量各不相同。训练数据集是从商业样品（HOPG、DLC、GC）和我们实验室合成的样品（GLCH、PLCH）收集的拉曼光谱。使用 532 nm 激光激发收集拉曼光谱。分类模型表明，第一主成分 (PC1) 是从无定形碳样品中分离晶体的决定性信息来源。 PC2 允许分离具有不同杂化程度（sp2 和 sp3）的非晶材料。最后，PC2 和 PC3 都有助于分离具有不同氢化程度的材料。使用文献报道的碳材料拉曼光谱库对分类模型进行了测试，结果显示预测准确度很高（97％）。这里提出的模型为使用拉曼光谱和机器学习对碳材料进行自动分类提供了途径。 ;

;碳材料呈现出独特的拉曼特征，该特征取决于各种因素，包括主要的碳杂化。获得了多种碳材料的参考光谱，并将其用作机器学习算法的训练集。该程序可以对文献中报道的拉曼光谱库进行自动分类，准确度很高（97%）。

;
;

;摘要

;

;主成分分析（PCA）和线性判别分析（LDA）用于根据拉曼光谱对不同类型的碳材料进行分类。所选参考材料为高取向热解石墨（HOPG）、类金刚石碳（DLC）、玻璃碳（GC）、氢化类石墨碳（GLCH）和氢化类聚合物碳（PLCH）。这些材料的结晶度、主要碳杂化和氢含量各不相同。训练数据集是从商业样品（HOPG、DLC、GC）和我们实验室合成的样品（GLCH、PLCH）收集的拉曼光谱。使用 532 nm 激光激发收集拉曼光谱。分类模型表明，第一主成分 (PC1) 是从无定形碳样品中分离晶体的决定性信息来源。 PC2 允许分离具有不同杂化程度的非晶材料（sp;2; 和 sp;3;）。最后，PC2 和 PC3 都有助于分离具有不同氢化程度的材料。使用文献报道的碳材料拉曼光谱库对分类模型进行了测试，结果显示预测准确度很高（97％）。这里介绍的模型为使用拉曼光谱和机器学习对碳材料进行自动分类提供了途径。

; Bruno G. daFonseca、Sapanbir S. Thind、Ian Booth、Alexandre G. Brolo研究文章用于散装 sp2 和 sp3 碳材料自动分类的机器学习方法10.1002/jrs.6608拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6608 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6608?af=R 研究文章 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6603?af=R Wed, 18 Oct 2023 04:24:40 -0700 2023-10-18T04:24:40-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录 10.1002/jrs.6603在紫外-可见光-红外激发下天体生物学相关生物样本和行星表面类似物的比较拉曼光谱拉曼光谱学杂志，EarlyView。这项研究证实了选择合适的激发激光波长对于避免/减少拉曼散射光谱中的光致发光至关重要，并由此实现模拟行星表面风化层的强发光生物样品和矿物混合物的拉曼特征的最佳对比度，与天体生物学相关。红外激发主要是为了使生物分子获得最佳性能，不仅提供低 PL 响应，而且比短波长激光的潜在损害也低。矿物相的识别在整个 UV-NIR 范围内都是可行的，而与硅基 CCD 相结合的绿色激光器可提供最佳的信噪比，因此可以在相对较低的激光强度下返回合理的拉曼信号。摘要：我们研究了从紫外到可见光再到红外（激发波长为 325、532、785 和 1064 nm）的广泛光学范围内激光选择的潜力，用于对地球相关的极端微生物（Xanthoria elegans、Buellia frigida、和绿藻）、碳水化合物分子以及作为模拟矿物混合物的火星和月球表面风化层模拟物（P-MRS、S-MRS、LRS 和 JSC-1）。我们表明，激光光子能量的优化为每个检查的样品提供了（至少一个选定的激发波长）高端质量拉曼光谱。在大多数情况下，对于生物样品来说，红外光谱范围是先进的，而可见光和紫外光谱范围内的激发通常有利于或至少足以准确识别/分辨率行星表面模拟物上照射激光点下的矿物相。紫外线激发并不总是能对所研究的生物分子中诱导的光致发光产生显着的拉曼斯托克斯响应对比度。生物样品拉曼光谱中最显着的特征被分配给它们的特定色素，也被认为是极端微生物的生物分子特征。每个特定激发源的具体优点和局限性的关键问题意味着研究如何从拉曼光谱中获得科学回报以进行外层生物勘探，例如，生物和地质光谱数据的单激发波长或双激发波长之间的最佳权衡。 ;

;本文展示了高分辨率准连续受激拉曼光谱在低波数旋转跃迁研究中的应用，下降至~11.5 cm;−1;。借助此功能，我们能够测量受 H;2; 扰动的 CO 纯旋转拉曼光谱在 77、180 和 298 K 下从线 S(0) 到 S(20) 的碰撞展宽，并得到相应的展宽系数。还讨论了光谱轮廓中是否存在显着的 AC Stark 展宽。

;
;

;摘要

;

;我们展示了高分辨率准连续（q-cw）受激拉曼光谱（SRS）在低频、纯稀释样品中分子的旋转跃迁以获得碰撞信息。在少数开创性的 q-cw SRS 旋转工作中遇到的主要问题，即由于跃迁的上下态之间的群体差异较小以及交流 (AC) 斯塔克效应的存在而导致的信号弱，已经得到解决：执行光束混合、分离和滤波的光学元件的改进使我们能够使用共线光束几何结构和三通道配置来增强拉曼信号。由 AC Stark 效应引起的线轮廓畸变已被测量并包含在光谱的数值处理中。借助这些扩展功能，我们已经能够记录波数低至 ;∼; 11.5 cm; ;−;1; 的受激拉曼跃迁，对应于 S (0) CO 分子的纯旋转跃迁。我们将该装置应用于 H;2; 扰动的 CO 旋转谱线的碰撞展宽研究，并获得了 S(0) 谱线的展宽系数77、180 和 298 K 下的 S(20)。这些各向异性系数与红外振动实验获得的系数之间的比较显示出极好的一致性。据我们所知，这是使用旋转 SRS 获取稀释气体样品中碰撞信息的首次演示。

;丹尼斯·帕雷德斯·罗伊巴斯、劳尔·Z·马丁内斯研究文章低频旋转跃迁的高分辨率受激拉曼光谱：受 H2 扰动的 CO 旋转 S 分支中碰撞展宽系数的获得10.1002/jrs.6582拉曼光谱杂志10.1002/jrs.6582 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6582?af=R 研究文章54 10 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6563?af=R Mon, 16 Oct 2023 01:12:29 -0700 2023-10-16T01:12:29-07:00 Wiley：拉曼光谱杂志：目录2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6563基于空间外差显微差分拉曼光谱的微塑料样品检测《拉曼光谱杂志》，第 54 卷，第 10 期，第 1090-1098 页，2023 年 10 月。为了实现微塑料的快速、准确检测，本文设计并搭建了空间外差显微差分拉曼光谱（SHMDRS）系统。通过空间外差光谱（SHS）与显微微分拉曼光谱（MDRS）相结合，获得了PS、PC、PP和HDPE四种微塑料样品的拉曼光谱。通过差分拉曼光谱去除荧光干扰，通过多重约束迭代算法成功恢复了四种微塑料样品的纯拉曼光谱。实验表明，所设计的SHMDRS系统具有高光通量、高分辨率、高信噪比的特点，在弱拉曼信号检测中具有一定的优势。摘要 微塑料作为一种新的全球污染物，近年来受到广泛关注。传统的微塑料检测技术存在信号弱、成本高、操作复杂等缺点。因此，本文设计并构建了一套用于微塑料检测的空间外差显微差分拉曼光谱（SHMDRS）系统。该系统将空间外差系统（SHS）与显微差分拉曼系统（MDRS）相结合。利用ZEMAX软件对系统进行仿真设计，并在实验平台上搭建了SHMDRS系统。 531.742 nm 和 532.567 nm 双波长激光器用作激发光源。对PS、PC、PP、HDPE四种微塑料样品进行了测试，验证了该系统的可行性。在积分时间10 s、激光功率200 mW的条件下，分别采用SHMDRS系统和色散光谱仪对微塑料样品进行检测。比较并计算了不同系统拉曼光谱的信噪比（SNR）。利用双波长激光获得了四种微塑料样品的差分拉曼光谱，并通过多重约束迭代算法恢复了四种微塑料样品的纯拉曼光谱。结果表明，SHMDRS系统的光谱分辨率为2.809 cm−1，光谱范围为255.47~2023.21 cm−1。 SHMDRS系统获得的拉曼光谱信噪比优于色散光谱仪，差分拉曼光谱可以有效去除荧光背景的干扰。该方法具有良好的发展前景。 ;

;为了实现微塑料的快速、准确检测，本文设计并搭建了空间外差显微微分拉曼光谱（SHMDRS）系统。通过空间外差光谱（SHS）与显微微分拉曼光谱（MDRS）相结合，获得了PS、PC、PP和HDPE四种微塑料样品的拉曼光谱。通过差分拉曼光谱去除荧光干扰，通过多重约束迭代算法成功恢复了四种微塑料样品的纯拉曼光谱。实验表明，所设计的SHMDRS系统具有高光通量、高分辨率、高信噪比的特点，在弱拉曼信号检测中具有一定的优势。

;
;

;摘要

;

;微塑料作为一种新的全球污染物，近年来受到广泛关注。传统的微塑料检测技术存在信号弱、成本高、操作复杂等缺点。因此，本文设计并构建了一套用于微塑料检测的空间外差显微差分拉曼光谱（SHMDRS）系统。该系统将空间外差系统（SHS）与显微差分拉曼系统（MDRS）相结合。利用ZEMAX软件对系统进行仿真设计，并在实验平台上搭建了SHMDRS系统。 The 531.742- and 532.567-nm dual-wavelength lasers were used as the excitation light source. Four kinds of microplastic samples, namely, PS, PC, PP, and HDPE, were tested to verify the feasibility of the system. Under the integration time of 10 s and the laser power of 200 mW, the microplastic samples were detected by the SHMDRS system and dispersive spectrometer, respectively. The signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of Raman spectra of different systems was compared and calculated. The differential Raman spectra of four kinds of microplastic samples were obtained by dual-wavelength laser, and the pure Raman spectra of four kinds of microplastic samples were restored by multiple constrained iterative algorithm. The results show that the spectral resolution of the SHMDRS system is 2.809 cm;−1;, and the spectral range is 255.47–2023.21 cm;−1;. The SNRs of the Raman spectra obtained by the SHMDRS system are better than those of the dispersive spectrometer, and the differential Raman spectroscopy can effectively remove the interference of the fluorescence background. This method has a good development prospect.

; Hui Yang, Qingsheng Xue, Fengqin Lu, Yang Dong, Fupeng Wang, Qian Li RESEARCH ARTICLE Detection of microplastic samples based on spatial heterodyne microscopic differential Raman spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6563 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6563 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6563?af=R RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 10 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6572?af=R Mon, 16 Oct 2023 01:12:29 -0700 2023-10-16T01:12:29-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6572 A simple model to simulate the Raman spectrum of methane in the range of 2800–3040 cm−1 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 10, Page 1150-1159, October 2023. We present a simple method to simulate the Raman spectrum of methane in natural gas at different pressures and concentrations of nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and ethane. A detailed description of the algorithm and the empirical parameters necessary for the simulation are provided. The method can be used to improve the accuracy of the Raman gas analysis of natural gas and other methane‐bearing media. Abstract Raman spectroscopy is a promising method to analyze natural gas. Measurement of hydrocarbon concentrations is required for quality control of this fuel. Despite the presence of intense characteristic peaks of hydrocarbons in the range of 2800–3040 cm−1, researchers avoid this region due to the overlap with a methane spectrum. This paper presents a simple method to simulate the Raman spectrum of methane in natural gas at different pressures and concentrations of nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and ethane. A detailed description of the algorithm and the empirical parameters necessary for the simulation are provided. The method can be used to improve the accuracy of the Raman gas analysis of natural gas and other methane‐bearing media. ;

;We present a simple method to simulate the Raman spectrum of methane in natural gas at different pressures and concentrations of nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and ethane. A detailed description of the algorithm and the empirical parameters necessary for the simulation are provided. The method can be used to improve the accuracy of the Raman gas analysis of natural gas and other methane-bearing media.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;Raman spectroscopy is a promising method to analyze natural gas. Measurement of hydrocarbon concentrations is required for quality control of this fuel. Despite the presence of intense characteristic peaks of hydrocarbons in the range of 2800–3040 cm;−1;, researchers avoid this region due to the overlap with a methane spectrum. This paper presents a simple method to simulate the Raman spectrum of methane in natural gas at different pressures and concentrations of nitrogen, carbon dioxide, and ethane. A detailed description of the algorithm and the empirical parameters necessary for the simulation are provided. The method can be used to improve the accuracy of the Raman gas analysis of natural gas and other methane-bearing media.

; Aleksandr S. Tanichev, Dmitry V. Petrov, Matvey A. Kostenko RESEARCH ARTICLE A simple model to simulate the Raman spectrum of methane in the range of 2800–3040 cm−1 10.1002/jrs.6572 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6572 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6572?af=R RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 10 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6573?af=R Mon, 16 Oct 2023 01:12:29 -0700 2023-10-16T01:12:29-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6573 Visible light‐enhanced and degradable SERS substrates based on g‐C3N4/Au NP hybrid structures Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 10, Page 1056-1063, October 2023. SERS substrate based on g‐C3N4/Au NP hybrid structures demonstrates visible light‐activated enhancement and degradation properties. Abstract In this study, a visible light‐activated and degradable surface‐enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) substrate was fabricated based on graphite carbon nitride (g‐C3N4) and gold nanoparticle (Au NP) hybrid structures. By using porous structure of g‐C3N4 as the support, Au NP arrays can be formed through sputtering of a thin Au film. Typical surface Raman enhancement effect can be observed by using p‐toluenethiol as the probe molecule. Interestingly, it was found that the Raman signal of probe molecules could be enhanced 2.7 times by pre‐illumination of visible light for a short time within 2 min, while the Raman signal decreased significantly about five times with further long‐term irradiation of more than 60 min. The electromagnetic enhancement effect of Au NP array on semiconductor materials with various extinction coefficients was studied by FDTD simulations. Furthermore, a charge transfer enhancement mechanism was proposed based on band structure of g‐C3N4/Au NP hybrid substrate and molecular orbitals. Our experimental and simulation results demonstrated an approach to construct a visible light‐activated SERS substrate with enhancement and degradation properties based on porous organic semiconductors. ;

;SERS substrate based on gC;3;N;4;/Au NP hybrid structures demonstrates visible light-activated enhancement and degradation properties.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;In this study, a visible light-activated and degradable surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy (SERS) substrate was fabricated based on graphite carbon nitride (gC;3;N;4;) and gold nanoparticle (Au NP) hybrid structures. By using porous structure of gC;3;N;4; as the support, Au NP arrays can be formed through sputtering of a thin Au film. Typical surface Raman enhancement effect can be observed by using ;p;-toluenethiol as the probe molecule. Interestingly, it was found that the Raman signal of probe molecules could be enhanced 2.7 times by pre-illumination of visible light for a short time within 2 min, while the Raman signal decreased significantly about five times with further long-term irradiation of more than 60 min. The electromagnetic enhancement effect of Au NP array on semiconductor materials with various extinction coefficients was studied by FDTD simulations. Furthermore, a charge transfer enhancement mechanism was proposed based on band structure of gC;3;N;4;/Au NP hybrid substrate and molecular orbitals. Our experimental and simulation results demonstrated an approach to construct a visible light-activated SERS substrate with enhancement and degradation properties based on porous organic semiconductors.

; Menghan Zhang, Jiayi Yin, Wenlong Song, Qinlu Qiu, Rongchuan Mao, Yu Yu, Kejian Ding, Songmei Wu RESEARCH ARTICLE Visible light‐enhanced and degradable SERS substrates based on g‐C3N4/Au NP hybrid structures 10.1002/jrs.6573 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6573 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6573?af=R RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 10 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6574?af=R Mon, 16 Oct 2023 01:12:29 -0700 2023-10-16T01:12:29-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6574 Atmospheric aerosol particles before, during, and after a convective dust event on the Jornada experimental range as measured using Raman hyperspectral imaging Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 10, Page 1114-1137, October 2023. An aerosol Raman hyperspectral imager collected and measured Raman spectra (RS) of particles in a desert in 15 or 20 min. Periods. RS were consistent with black carbon (DGC), carbonates, quartz, and luminescent matter. A convective dust event was concurrent with changes in numbers of some RS. Abstract The effects of winds and local mineralogy on ambient aerosol composition are poorly understood. We measured the Raman spectra (RS) of ambient aerosol particles on the Jornada Experimental Range, a desert location in southern New Mexico, used these RS to group spectra by composition or spectral features, and compared the numbers of RS with the winds and minerology. An aerosol Raman hyperspectral imager was used to collect particles onto a tape and measure a hyperspectral Raman image in 15‐ or 20‐min intervals. Over a 48 h period, 6306 RS were above the thresholds used and were analyzed further. Multiple RS may originate from the same particle. Of these 6306 RS, 2567 were classified as luminescence; 2647 contained the D and G peaks of DG Carbon (DGC, which includes soots, black carbon, and similar materials); 43 exhibited peaks consistent with CH stretching; and 130, 102, and 29 RS were consistent with quartz, carbonates (calcite and dolomite), and potassium feldspar, respectively. A convective dust event was concurrent with an increase in the number of RS of luminescent particles >;20X the median; numbers of DGC RS in the interquartile range of DGC for the entire measurement period; RS consistent with quartz, calcite, iron oxides, feldspar, and anatase; and no RS consistent with oxalates or nitrates. This work shows that hyperspectral Raman imaging can help understand the time‐dependent composition of ambient aerosol particles at time resolutions below an hour. ;

;An aerosol Raman hyperspectral imager collected and measured Raman spectra (RS) of particles in a desert in 15 or 20 min. Periods. RS were consistent with black carbon (DGC), carbonates, quartz, and luminescent matter. A convective dust event was concurrent with changes in numbers of some RS.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;The effects of winds and local mineralogy on ambient aerosol composition are poorly understood. We measured the Raman spectra (RS) of ambient aerosol particles on the Jornada Experimental Range, a desert location in southern New Mexico, used these RS to group spectra by composition or spectral features, and compared the numbers of RS with the winds and minerology. An aerosol Raman hyperspectral imager was used to collect particles onto a tape and measure a hyperspectral Raman image in 15- or 20-min intervals. Over a 48 h period, 6306 RS were above the thresholds used and were analyzed further. Multiple RS may originate from the same particle. Of these 6306 RS, 2567 were classified as luminescence; 2647 contained the D and G peaks of DG Carbon (DGC, which includes soots, black carbon, and similar materials); 43 exhibited peaks consistent with CH stretching; and 130, 102, and 29 RS were consistent with quartz, carbonates (calcite and dolomite), and potassium feldspar, respectively. A convective dust event was concurrent with an increase in the number of RS of luminescent particles >20X the median; numbers of DGC RS in the interquartile range of DGC for the entire measurement period; RS consistent with quartz, calcite, iron oxides, feldspar, and anatase; and no RS consistent with oxalates or nitrates. This work shows that hyperspectral Raman imaging can help understand the time-dependent composition of ambient aerosol particles at time resolutions below an hour.

; David C. Doughty, Robert E. Dumais, Tyler R. Richman, Steven C. Hill RESEARCH ARTICLE Atmospheric aerosol particles before, during, and after a convective dust event on the Jornada experimental range as measured using Raman hyperspectral imaging 10.1002/jrs.6574 Journal of Raman Spectroscopy 10.1002/jrs.6574 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6574?af=R RESEARCH ARTICLE 54 10 https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/jrs.6576?af=R Mon, 16 Oct 2023 01:12:29 -0700 2023-10-16T01:12:29-07:00 Wiley: Journal of Raman Spectroscopy: Table of Contents 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 2023 年 10 月 1 日，星期日 00:00:00 -0700 10.1002/jrs.6576 Identification of blood cell changes in pediatric oncological patients through Raman spectroscopy Journal of Raman Spectroscopy, Volume 54, Issue 10, Page 1043-1055, October 2023. Raman spectroscopy has been studied as a tool for the differential diagnosis of cancer through blood cells, as it has been shown great ability to identify spectral information regarding the cell's biochemical constitution and biomarker compounds present in the blood. Principal component analysis of the Raman spectra suggested occurrences of higher concentration of cytochrome c in normal samples, being an important biochemical marker that discriminates between healthy and neoplastic states, and higher concentration of phenylalanine in the leukemic samples. Abstract This study aimed to use the Raman spectroscopy technique to identify biochemical changes in blood cell samples of healthy, leukemic, and non‐leukemic subjects by principal component analysis (PCA) and to discriminate the groups by partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS‐DA). For the study, 121 blood samples were collected from healthy children and adolescents among those with leukemia and other types of cancer (non‐leukemics). A volume of 80 μl of blood cells was placed in an aluminum sample holder and submitted to dispersive Raman spectroscopy (laser: 830 nm and 250 mW), with an exposure time of 30 s. A total of 308 Raman spectra were analyzed and indicated significant differences in the bands referred to nucleic acids (671 and 756 cm−1), amino acids (671, 1,215, and 1,544 cm−1), proteins (756, 1,215, 1,430, 1,531, and 1,548 cm−1), β‐carotene (1,531 cm−1), and cytochrome c (756 and 1,371 cm−1), showing higher intensity in normal samples. The analysis of the PCA variables (PCs) showed that there was a higher concentration of cytochrome c (633, 749, 855, 1,004, 1,127, 1,212, 1,370, 1,433, 1,531, and 1,614 cm−1), in the normal samples, and a higher concentration of phenylalanine (1,004 cm−1) was observed in the leukemic samples with statistically significant (ANOVA, p < 0.05). Discriminant analysis by PLS‐DA model classified the spectra into the groups normal (healthy), leukemic, and non‐leukemic with accuracy of 67.5%; when considering normal versus cancer, the accuracy increased to 98.3%, with sensitivity of 100% and specificity of 87.8%. Results demonstrated the applicability of Raman spectroscopy for analyzing biochemical compounds in blood cells, thus identifying the spectral differences between the groups normal, leukemic, and non‐leukemic (with other types of cancer). However, it presented a low accuracy due to classification errors when discriminating between the groups leukemic and non‐leukemic. ;

;Raman spectroscopy has been studied as a tool for the differential diagnosis of cancer through blood cells, as it has been shown great ability to identify spectral information regarding the cell's biochemical constitution and biomarker compounds present in the blood. Principal component analysis of the Raman spectra suggested occurrences of higher concentration of cytochrome c in normal samples, being an important biochemical marker that discriminates between healthy and neoplastic states, and higher concentration of phenylalanine in the leukemic samples.

;
;

;Abstract

;

;This study aimed to use the Raman spectroscopy technique to identify biochemical changes in blood cell samples of healthy, leukemic, and non-leukemic subjects by principal component analysis (PCA) and to discriminate the groups by partial least squares discriminant analysis (PLS-DA). For the study, 121 blood samples were collected from healthy children and adolescents among those with leukemia and other types of cancer (non-leukemics). A volume of 80 μl of blood cells was placed in an aluminum sample holder and submitted to dispersive Raman spectroscopy (laser: 830 nm and 250 mW), with an exposure time of 30 s. A total of 308 Raman spectra were analyzed and indicated significant differences in the bands referred to nucleic acids (671 and 756 cm;−1;), amino acids (671, 1,215, and 1,544 cm;−1;), proteins (756, 1,215, 1,430, 1,531, and 1,548 cm;−1;), β-carotene (1,531 cm;−1;), and cytochrome c (756 and 1,371 cm;−1;), showing higher intensity in normal samples. The analysis of the PCA variables (PCs) showed that there was a higher concentration of cytochrome c (633, 749, 855, 1,004, 1,127, 1,212, 1,370, 1,433, 1,531, and 1,614 cm;−1;), in the normal samples, and a higher concentration of phenylalanine (1,004 cm;−1;) was observed in the leukemic samples with statistically significant (ANOVA, ;p; < 0.05). Discriminant analysis by PLS-DA model classified the spectra into the groups normal (healthy), leukemic, and non-leukemic with accuracy of 67.5%; when considering normal versus cancer, the accuracy increased to 98.3%, with sensitivity of 100% and specificity of 87.8%. Results demonstrated the applicability of Raman spectroscopy for analyzing biochemical compounds in blood cells, thus identifying the spectral differences between the groups normal, leukemic, and non-leukemic (with other types of cancer). However, it presented a low accuracy due to classification errors when discriminating between the groups leukemic and non-leukemic.
